;周日，财政司司长陈茂波宣布政府有意与

;

;尽管政府努力保持经济复苏势头令人钦佩，但陈的提议引发了人们对夜市盈利能力的质疑。新业务以及本已陷入困境的餐厅的竞争加剧。

;

;该提案的最大缺点是它似乎忽视了香港充满活力的当地文化和自然魅力。与其说是政府主办的新夜市，不如看看这座城市已有的东西？

;

;香港长期以来一直以不夜城而闻名，而兰桂坊无疑是其中最著名的夜生活代表。在大流行之前，这里是晚上的热点地区。东西方文化的人们在酒吧结束了一天的工作，聚集在一起享受饮料、音乐和彼此的陪伴。

;

;它是香港拥抱自由西方生活方式的象征，尽管这座城市一直保持着其中国文化根源。

;

;然而，许多当地人更喜欢晚上在大排档（露天大排档）和熟食中心与朋友一起享用热餐和冰镇啤酒。

;

;尽管大牌档和美食集市显然深受香港人的喜爱，但政府似乎更多地将其视为需要管理的主题，而不是需要推广的景点。除了 2017 年短暂提及香港旅游发展局对推广大排档和熟食中心的想法持开放态度外，此后几乎没有采取任何行动。

;

;亚洲城市以夜生活而闻名，从从东京新宿入夜后的喧嚣到台北夜市。这些旅游目的地本身就是充满活力的当地文化和传统，并不是政府精心规划的结果。

;

;这些地方吸引游客是因为它们讲述了故事。香港政府若想振兴城市的夜生活，首先要考虑这座城市要讲述什么样的故事。

;

;以台湾为例，台北的夜市最为出名，但其实这样的市场并不多。岛上各处都有发现。最大、最著名的夜市，如士林夜市和饶河夜市，是管理完善的景点，为当地人和游客提供服务。但它们并不是这样开始的。

;

;像许多最好的旅游景点一样，这些市场有自发的、无计划的、不起眼的开始，产生了自己的人气并开始腾飞。当政府介入时，已经建立了成熟的市场和繁荣的夜生活，准备进行监管和推广。

;

;香港也有自己的吸引力：大排档和熟食中心。< /p>;

;对于许多游客，尤其是来自中国大陆的游客来说，这些是香港街道上色彩缤纷的标志，是许多香港电影熟悉的背景。对于香港人来说，这些是他们最熟悉、最喜欢的地方。

;

;大排档和熟食中心是政府宣传的天黑后景点的完美现成候选。

;

; p>;

;政府不需要费尽心思来提升香港的夜生活吸引力，寻找举办更多音乐会、新会议或新国际比赛的主办方。是的，这些活动也吸引了游客，但它们是暂时的，甚至是一次性的。而且它们很可能会带来短暂的游客激增，而不会增加大多数人的夜生活享受。

;

;政府应该做的是审视其管理的香港文化的特征，就大排档和熟食中心而言，欣赏它们作为文化魅力的独特体现，并抵制将它们视为低俗的倾向。

;

;越来越多的游客和当地人更喜欢坚韧的品质闪闪发光：摆脱现代、大规模、有计划的活动，转而寻找当地历史和文化的小型、多彩、有机的部分。

;

;这是政府重新审视 dai 理念的绝佳机会排洞和美食集市作为旅游景点。在此过程中，它必须重新考虑它想讲述香港夜生活的哪些故事，以及香港人的生活。

;

;他补充说：“这意味着在我们拥有的地区投入更多能力，如果有必要的话，我们肯定会考虑在未来再次这样做。”

;Ovy Sabrina 在印度尼西亚通过传播面条包、咖啡袋、吸管和塑料袋来对抗塑料垃圾广阔群岛周围的其他垃圾 - 埋在环保砖中。

;

;她的家人知道在环境问题上不要妨碍她，尤其是五年前，当她提出用环保砖块制作砖块的想法时使用一次性塑料来对抗污染和首都雅加达的高排放建筑热潮。

;

;利用家族传统砖厂的机械，并利用她的零废物生活方式，萨布丽娜和她的朋友诺维塔·谭推出了他们的绿色环保项目2018 年，建筑材料初创公司 Rebricks。

;

;“我的家人通常告诉我去做任何我想做的事。如果人们不同意我的观点，我仍然会这样做。”这位 37 岁的女士说道。她经常与她的兄弟姐妹在共同家里的家庭垃圾分类和回收问题上发生争执。 “我们总是对那些想要参与回收计划的人说，‘放手去做’。”

;

;随着该地区一半以上的人口居住在城市，并且这一数字还在不断上升，亚洲的城市人口随着财富的增加和财富的增加而猛增。人们追求更好的生活，这给基础设施、公共服务和经济适用住房带来了巨大压力。

;

;繁华的雅加达拥有 1000 万居民，这里散布着排放大量温室气体的建筑工地，正在修建新火车队列、购物中心、休闲中心、公寓和办公室。

;

;但在地面上，居民与街头小贩争夺空间，并与城市臭名昭著的交通拥堵、经常发生的洪水和令人窒息的空气污染作斗争。

;

; p>;

;随着印度尼西亚首都的发展，废物收集和回收服务一直难以跟上。

;

;一次性塑料（例如吸管、糖果包、塑料袋和咖啡袋）通常被发送到已经满的垃圾填埋场，被非正式的垃圾收集者烧毁，或者干脆扔进城市的运河。

;

;为了解决印度尼西亚垃圾和污染城市发展的双重挑战，Rebricks 在 2019 年底取得了突破，创建了一个使用符合行业标准的一次性塑料废物制成的砖。

;

;该公司将火山灰、山石、印度尼西亚各地家庭捐赠的塑料废物和水泥混合制成砖，不像普通砖那样含有沙子

;

;它为慈善机构和其他团体提供服务，为贫困社区建造经济适用房和卫生设施。

;

;巴厘岛的“河流勇士”清理印度尼西亚海滩和水道的废物

;

;萨布丽娜说，该公司的价格具有竞争力，而其砖块（与传统砖一样耐用且坚固）是不可燃的，而且其生产的铺路石在潮湿时也不会变得湿滑。

;< p>;Rebricks 的网站称其生产能力为每天 100 平方米（1,076 平方英尺）。

;

;但 Sabrina 拒绝透露销售细节，并补充说产量受到公司基本制砖技术的限制，并且劳动密集型机械，塑料废物捐赠常常超过对砖块的需求。

;

;这家初创公司利用社交媒体呼吁塑料废物，正在与政府谈判，为补贴住房项目提供材料。< /p>;

;“作为一个发展中国家，我们不可能说‘不发展’，”萨布丽娜说。 “发展将继续下去，但至少如果同时回收废物，它会有所帮助。”

;

;建筑和建筑行业约占全球能源相关排放量的 40% –行业专家表示，减少排放对于各国履行其国际气候和环境承诺至关重要。

;

;该行业约一半的排放来自建筑，其余来自建筑物的供暖或制冷以及供电方式，一旦使用。

;

;气候变化团队成员 Lea Ranalder 表示，该行业还占所有提取材料的 50%，而仅水泥生产就占全球碳排放量的 7%。联合国人居署是一个促进可持续人类住区的联合国机构。

;

;该行业消耗的材料中只有不到 9% 是循环利用的（回收或再利用），从而形成“我们建造，我们丢弃”的理念” 心态，她指出。

;

;“当我们谈论气候变化以及我们如何应对气候变化时，建筑行业是被忽视的巨人，”她说。 “如果不真正解决该行业的问题，当我们谈论气候危机时，我们就无法实现这一目标。”

;

;改革分散的行业是复杂的。行业专家表示，亚洲许多开发商都关注利润和承受能力，认为绿色设计和建筑材料价格昂贵。

;

;建造绿色建筑会使成本增加 3% 至 5%，具体取决于联合国环境规划署 (UNEP) 的建筑专家乔纳森·杜温 (Jonathan Duwyn) 表示，“关于建筑类型”。

;

;但随着时间的推移，随着建筑物的运营成本降低，它会变得更便宜，他说，补充说，“总体而言，成本并没有高出很多，而且我们做得越多，成本就会下降”。

;

;此外，培训行业劳动力 - 并确保大学和建筑学校促进可持续发展 - 是专家表示，这是创造高薪绿色就业机会的巨大机会。

;

;“如果政府承诺投资和扩大绿色建筑开发，这将激励建筑工人追求这些类型的技能，因为他们知道，倡导循环经济的艾伦·麦克阿瑟基金会 (Ellen MacArthur Foundation) 的尼克·杰弗里斯 (Nick Jeffries) 说道。

;

;印度尼西亚建筑师安迪·苏巴吉奥 (Andi Subagio) 的下一个项目将是雅加达新建筑群外的步行广场快速公交站。

;

;Subagio 坐在他用 Rebricks 材料设计和建造的雅加达餐厅里，他热衷于让自己的城市变得更加可持续发展，他说这家餐厅更好地利用了自然通风，而不是安装空调.

;

;这位 33 岁的人看到了现代与传统设计和建筑材料相结合的巨大好处，并补充说，用钢材、混凝土和玻璃建造的高耸结构是一种相对较新的趋势。

;< p>;“传统（设计）是我们可以学习如何更可持续地生活的地方，”SASO建筑工作室创始人Subagio说。

;

;印度尼西亚的“雨林城市”首都会给居民带来健康风险吗？

;

; h3>;

;联合国环境规划署的杜温还表示，该行业应该在建筑中减少使用新材料，并采取更多措施来延长现有建筑物的使用寿命。他说，自然通风、利用自然和增加遮阳对于帮助温暖的世界降温也至关重要。

;

;对于建筑材料，他指出用于隔热的生物基废物和可持续砍伐的木材作为选择。< /p>;

;然而，在社会上，复兴旧技术往往很困难，因为许多人认为生活在现代混凝土建筑中标志着生活的成功，他补充道。

;

;亚洲是一些技术的发源地。增长最快的建筑市场，在 Covid-19 大流行期间暂停后，项目正在加快步伐。

;

;“有大量绿色建筑正在建设中，但其建设速度被规划不那么周密的建筑所赶超。惠灵顿 Herenga Waka-Victoria 大学文化人类学讲师 Eli Elinoff 表示：她接触过的大型开发商往往更关注成本而不是环境。

;

;例如，这些开发商可能会建造一千个新房屋，通常会优先选择材料供应商，并且经常将尝试新事物视为有风险的。 ”，她说。

;

;Sabrina 的公司并没有被吓倒，计划今年在中爪哇开设第二家工厂，并在度假胜地巴厘岛开设另一家工厂，她希望明年开始在学校教授有关塑料垃圾的意识。

;

;“也许我们可以在印度尼西亚较小的岛屿上复制这一点，这样我们就可以产生更大的影响，”她说。

;内地繁殖专家团队抵港协助海洋公园努力帮助该市的两只大熊猫“迎迎”和“乐乐”繁殖。

;

;来自四川省的专家将与主题公园的管理员合作，帮助这两只哺乳动物繁殖。中国保护大熊猫研究中心都江堰基地熊猫管理负责人周四表示。

;

;他补充说，此次合作将重点关注繁育过程中涉及的技术和准备工作。

; >;

;“由于温度、环境和缺乏可用配偶等多种因素，盈盈和乐乐的繁殖很复杂，”他说，并指出该物种的繁殖季节是从七月到九月。< /p>;

;他解释说，生活在野外的雄性大熊猫会与竞争对手竞争，只有获胜者才能与雌性大熊猫交配。

;

;海洋公园发言人透露，都江堰中心和雅加达海洋公园的两位专家“碧峰谷中心已于上周抵达香港。

;

;虽然两只大熊猫在三月份尝试自然交配并进行了人工授精程序，但发言人表示盈盈今年不可能怀孕。

;

;中国卧龙自然保护区再次发现罕见的全白大熊猫

;

;“虽然盈盈表现出怀孕或假怀孕大熊猫的典型行为和荷尔蒙变化，但不幸的是经评估，确定今年不会产仔。”

;

;自2011年以来，香港一直未能成功繁殖大熊猫。

;

;香港仅存两只大熊猫“迎迎”和“乐乐”大约一周前，这座城市庆祝了他们的 18 岁生日。它们的年龄相当于人类的54岁。

;

;黄说，都江堰中心和海洋公园多年来在该物种的饲养和繁殖方面交流了知识，并解释说，公园的一名管理员现在正在接受海洋公园的培训。

;

;该中心是四川省四个大熊猫研究所之一，在 2008 年四川地震后，香港政府拨款 1.29 亿元人民币（1770 万美元）于 2012 年进行了重建。

;

;香港有新熊猫？海洋公园，城市正在讨论从北京获得一对

;

;黄说，鉴于交配数量较多，大多数大熊猫都出生在卧龙中心。

;

;他补充说，都江堰中心是大熊猫的栖息地。 41 只大熊猫生活在半圈养的庇护所中，其中一些大熊猫可以在约 200 万平方英尺的区域内漫步。

;

;野外生活着 1,800 多只大熊猫，其中大部分生活在四川，而大约有 600 只被圈养在大陆的各个自然保护区。

;

;美国联邦法官周四驳回了一项针对佛罗里达州法律的临时救济请求，该法律限制中国公民在该州购买房产。

;

;美国佛罗里达州塔拉哈西地区法官艾伦·温莎(Allen Winsor)反对授予初步禁令的裁决意味着该州法律将继续有效，直到法院就案情作出裁决

;

;该法律于 7 月 1 日生效，限制任何在“关注国家”“居住”的人在佛罗里达州购买房产，除非他们是美国公民或永久居民。 The designated countries of concern were China, Russia, Iran, North Korea, Cuba, Venezuela and Syria.

;

;The law imposes more limits on those domiciled in China. In Florida law, a person's place of domicile is where he has a good-faith intent to establish his home permanently or indefinitely, regardless of his current physical location.

;

;While those domiciled in the other targeted countries are restricted from owning property within 10 miles of any military installation or critical infrastructure facility, foreigners domiciled in China are restricted from owning any property – regardless of proximity.

;

;Chinese residents in Florida sue state over property ownership ban

;

;After Governor Ron DeSantis approved the law in May, four Chinese citizens and a real-estate brokerage that serves Chinese clients filed a lawsuit against the state and sought the injunction. They argued that the law was discriminatory, vague, violated fair housing standards and was pre-empted by federal law.

;

;In signing the bill, DeSantis said it was part of Florida standing up against the Chinese Communist Party, which he called the US' “greatest geopolitical threat”.

;

;Earlier drafts of the bill called for barring Chinese citizens and others from buying real estate within 20 miles of military bases and critical infrastructure but were eased somewhat after an uproar from the state's Asian-American community.

;

;The law now offers a narrow exception: a person domiciled in China who either has a valid non-tourist US visa or has been granted asylum in the US is permitted to buy residential property, but only if the property is less than two acres and located farther than five miles from a military installation.

;

;The US Department of Justice supported the lawsuit, filing a “statement of interest” in June that argues the Florida legislation violates the federal Fair Housing Act as well as the Constitution, specifically the equal protection clause of the 14th Amendment.

;

;The department contended that the law would “not advance the state's purported goal of increasing public safety” and that the plaintiffs were “likely to succeed on the merits of these claims”.

;

;But in his order on Thursday, Winsor said that the plaintiffs had “not shown a substantial likelihood of success on the merits”, which he noted was “the most important” of four factors required for a preliminary injunction.

;

;The other three factors are that: plaintiffs would suffer “irreparable injury”; face a threatened injury that “outweighs whatever damage the proposed injunction may cause” defendants; and the injunction would not be adverse to the public interest.

;

;Ron DeSantis lashes out at China and corporate power in campaign speech

;

;In his ruling, Winsor found that the law “does not facially discriminate against non-citizens based on race or ancestry …[or] on 'the particular country in which one was born'”.

;

;“It would apply to a person of Chinese descent domiciled in China the same way it would apply to a person not of Chinese descent domiciled in China,” he noted.

;

;Responding to the ruling, the National Asian Pacific American Bar Association called the Florida law a “textbook example of invidious discrimination”.

;

;The association's statement continued: “The plain sweep of [Senate Bill 264] not only places restrictions on individuals from China and certain other countries, including those lawfully present in the United States, in purchasing property, but it also imposes greater criminal penalties on Chinese buyers than for those from other restricted countries.”

;

;“SB 264 bears a chilling resemblance to past unconstitutional alien land laws that violated the equal protection and due process clauses of the United States Constitution.”

;

;A long-time stalwart of the party, Bolton said in an online discussion hosted by the Foreign Press Association that a reluctance among some in the party to defend Ukraine against Russia and engage more in the Middle East hands Beijing more influence in those regions. ;

;Bolton pointed to Beijing's key role in brokering peace between Saudi Arabia and Iran as an example of China's growing clout in the region.

;

;China, Russia and Iran launched joint naval exercises in the Gulf of Oman shortly afterwards, as the US was hosting the Middle East's largest maritime drills nearby.

;

;“Within the Republican Party, let's be clear, the virus of isolationism is unleashed again,” Bolton said, referring to Trump's position as the front-running Republican nominee for next year's presidential election.

;

;The former president has never condemned Russia's war against Ukraine, and according to Bolton, would not necessarily maintain a hard line against Iran in a theoretical second term as president because “he doesn't follow coherent policies; it's all what in the moment benefits him”.

;

;Bolton, who has advocated for a “pro-American” foreign policy since he started his career in the administration of Ronald Reagan in the 1980s, has emerged as one of Trump's harshest Republican critics.

;

;Following the four criminal indictments handed up against the former president in the past six months – two of them for his role in efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 election – Bolton has assailed Trump mostly for abandoning Reagan's legacy of aggressive responses to international threats to American interests.

;

;How China's Saudi-Iran deal shows Beijing's Mideast influence

;

;Shortly after leaving the White House, Bolton alleged in a tell-all memoir about his time in Trump's administration that the former president sought help from China's President Xi Jinping to win the 2020 election by asking his counterpart to boost imports of American agricultural products.

;

;Trump said on social media after the book's publication that it was “made up of lies and fake stories” and described his former national security adviser as “a disgruntled boring fool who only wanted to go to war”.

;

;“It's part of the problem when you have a naturally dovish party fighting war and a naturally hawkish party in opposition, and it makes things confusing,” Bolton said.

;

;“I think Republicans by and large remain a Reaganite party, not a Trump party, when it comes to national security, but that question is somewhat more open now than it was before.”

;

;Reagan was most remembered in the foreign policy domain for a hard line against the Soviet Union, including an aggressive US-led Western force posture against the bloc's military.

;

;Bolton maintained the same approach in his many foreign policy posts, including interim US ambassador to the United Nations under former president George W. Bush in 2005 and 2006.

;

;While most Republicans, including House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, call for greater efforts to defend Taiwan against Beijing's People's Liberation Army, many of them – also including McCarthy – have questioned the need for continued aid to Ukraine.

;

;Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, Trump's closest rival for the Republican nomination, made headlines in March for calling Russia's invasion of Ukraine a “territorial dispute”. ;

;China hawk Bolton to meet President Tsai during week-long Taiwan trip

;

;“There's a view that … China is not only the main threat for the rest of this century, but the only threat for the rest of this century, and that we have to focus all of our attention on East Asia and particularly on Taiwan, and have to ditch secondary areas of concern like the Middle East or like Europe,” Bolton said.

;

;“What worries me is that people who say we shouldn't pay attention to threats [in Europe and the Middle East], but we do care about threats to Taiwan [and] that that position lasts right up until there's a threat out from Taiwan,” he said.

;

;“And these same people then say, 'You know, it's a little too far away', and we lose in all three areas.”

;

;She told CBC her son kept saying: “I don't want to die, mummy.”

;In the Northwest Territories alone, 268 wildfires have already burned more than 21,000 sq km (8,100 square miles).

;Officials said evacuations from the Northwest Territories have so far been safe and orderly, and that evacuees from the capital who can't find their own accommodation can get support in three centres in the nearby province of Alberta that were expected to open by noon on Thursday.

;Eight communities totalling nearly 6,800 people, or 15 per cent of the Northwest Territories' population, have already left, Mike Westwick, the region's fire information officer, said earlier in the day.

;The US has also seen devastating wildfires, including one on the Hawaiian island of Maui, which killed more than 100 people and destroyed a historic town.

;Ukraine bombarded by missiles hours before Russia hosts security conference

;

;German Defence Minister Boris Pistorius welcomed the agreement, calling Arrow 3 “essential to be able to protect Germany from ballistic missile attacks in future”. His ministry added that Berlin aimed to integrate the system into Nato air defences.

;

;The Arrow 3 can intercept ballistic missiles fired from a distance of up to 2,400km (1,490 miles), according to IAI.

;

;Partly US-financed, the Arrow system was developed and produced by IAI in partnership with Boeing.

;

;IAI would set up new infrastructure for the German programme and hire new engineers and production employees in Israel and in the United States, said Moshe Patel, director of the Israel Missile Defence Organisation.

;

;“The German government wants it to be exactly as the system that we use,” he told journalists in an online briefing, adding half of the components would be produced in the United States by an American subsidiary of IAI.

;

;Germany is buying the “full architecture” of the system that can protect its citizens across the country, Patel said. “I can't elaborate more than this, but there is a lot of attention from other nations, specifically in Europe, to have the Arrow 3 weapons system,” he said.

;

;IAI president Boaz Levy said Arrow 3 was a “mobile system”.

;

;“You can shift it according to your threats, and that's why Germany is buying the system that can be utilised according to its own requirements,” Levy said.

;

;Israel successfully tests new laser missile defence system

;

;The deal makes Israel a “significant” player, said Miri Eisin, a former Israeli military intelligence colonel. “It means that Israel is not just a regional actor” but is now on the world stage, she said, adding the system was purely “defensive”.

;

;The system was first deployed at an Israeli air force base in 2017 and has been used to protect Israel against attacks from Iran and Syria.

;

;The final contract for the deal is expected to be signed by the end of 2023 after it is approved by the parliaments of both Germany and Israel, the Israeli defence ministry said. Berlin expects the Arrow 3 system to be delivered in the final quarter of 2025.

;

;The German government has led a push to bolster Nato's air defences in Europe after seeing Russia's relentless missile strikes on Ukraine, urging allies to buy deterrence systems together.

;

;More than a dozen European countries have so far signed up to the so-called European Sky Shield initiative.

;The US Commerce Department on Thursday said it will impose preliminary anti-dumping duties on tin-plated steel imports from Canada, Germany and China, sparing several other countries in a decision that drew some relief from food can manufacturers that had feared higher tariffs.

;

;The department said the highest preliminary anti-dumping duties of 122.5 per cent will be imposed on tin mill steel imported from China, including the country's largest producer, Baoshan Iron and Steel.

;

;The department will impose preliminary duties of 7.02 per cent on tin mill imports from German producers, including Thyssenkrupp and 5.29 per cent on imports from Canadian producers, including ArcelorMittal DOFASCO.

;

;No duties will be imposed on the shiny silver metal – widely used in cans for food, paint, aerosol products and other containers – imported from Britain, the Netherlands, South Korea, Taiwan and Turkey, the Commerce Department added.

;

;A Commerce Department official told reporters that producers in Canada, Germany and China were found to be selling tin mill steel at prices below those in their home markets.

;

;China's rates were higher because a lack of cooperation from a major producer in the investigation led to an “adverse inference” determination, while other respondents could not prove that they were independent of the Chinese government, the official added.

;

;The closely watched case was initiated in February after a petition from a single US steelmaker, Cleveland-Cliffs, alleged foreign dumping in the tin-plate sector, which has seen several US production facilities close in recent years.

;

;The Commerce Department in June announced preliminary anti-subsidy duties of 543 per cent on tin mill imports from Baoshan Iron and Steel and 89 per cent on those from all other Chinese producers as part of a separate, parallel investigation. The other countries cited in Thursday's decision were not subject to anti-subsidy investigations.

;

;Why is China's steel sector investing US$100 billion in coal-fired plants?

;

;The Can Manufacturers Institute, a trade group, argued before the decision that because US steelmakers currently produce less than half of the tin-plate needed for domestic can manufacturing, any new import duties will lead to higher material costs and food prices at a time when inflation remains elevated.

;

;A bipartisan letter from members of Congress in June also argued that high anti-dumping duties would raise costs for canned packaging for food and aerosol products and could help Chinese producers of canned goods, leading to increased canned food imports from China.

;

;But the duties were significantly less than initially feared. In its initial petition, Cleveland-Cliffs asked the Commerce Department to imposed anti-dumping duties of 79.6 per cent on imports from Canada, 70.2 per cent on Germany, 111.92 per cent on Britain, up to 110.5 per cent on South Korea, up to 296 per cent on the Netherlands, up to 60 per cent on Taiwan and up to 97.2 per cent on Turkey.

;

;In a statement, the Can Manufacturers Institute said it was “thankful” that most of the high duties requested by Cleveland-Cliffs were not imposed.

;

;“We are hopeful the final Commerce determination will eliminate the proposed duties on Canadian and German tin mill steel,” said Robert Budway, the group's president.

;

;“US tin plate prices already remain the highest in the world due to the 232 tariffs, placing domestic can makers at a competitive disadvantage to foreign imports of unfilled steel cans and foreign filled food products,” Budway said, referring to the “Section 232” tariffs on global steel and aluminium imports first imposed by the Trump administration.

;

;China accounts for about 14 per cent and Canada and Germany account for about 30 per cent of US tin mill steel imports, the Commerce Department official said, while the remaining half is accounted for by the UK, the Netherlands, South Korea, Taiwan and Turkey.

;

;Climate-based tariffs on Chinese steel, aluminium could be 'test run' by US, EU

;

;The tariffs decision was announced less than a week after Cleveland-Cliffs announced a buyout offer of its major competitor in the tin-plate sector, US Steel, an acquisition that would accelerate consolidation among American steel producers.

;

;Cleveland-Cliffs Chairman Lourenco Goncalves has repeatedly argued in favour of the need to maintain the 25 per cent Section 232 national security tariffs on imported steel imposed by the Trump administration.

;

;Cleveland-Cliffs in 2020 acquired AK Steel and ArcelorMittal's US assets, making it the largest US producer of blast-furnace steel made from iron ore.
